comment: Smooth, sweet and balanced, taste of orange cherry and honey with hint of vanilla, full and lingering finish

Received as a graduation gift from my pops. First “good” Irish whiskey I’ve had. Drank out of a glass and let sit for about 10 minutes. 

Nose: Fruity, berries. A bit of peach. And a tad of honey. Reminded me of cognac in a way. 

Taste: Like the sweet side of spices. Fruity with some bite. 

Finish: A smooth, slow burn. Definitely a whiskey but not harsh whatsoever.
Wonderful of course, though at first I thought I had a moldy cork, it was so dark and musty. Instant classic.
My first real try at good whiskey and this didn't disappoint.  Very smooth.  Can't wait to try more like it.
Amazing flavors of cherry, vanilla, oak, butter, yeast, and a slight metallic copper taste.
Sweet, spicy finish. Neat.  I like it better without water.
Incredibly smooth, but full of flavor. It’s a lighter whisky, a little sweet, no smoke at all. Little slice on finish.
Subtle but still a lot of flavor. Light but still spicy, with a balanced sweetness.
Very good. All kinds of flavor. Rich in caramel & not spicy. Very smooth burn going down. Definitely keep it in your stash for special occasions.
As far as an Irish whiskey goes, it doesn't get much better than this. The taste is fantastic with no alcohol burn. Recommend for a special occasion due to the price.
nice taste but too much alcohol burn
it's ok. I think I prefer a 19.99 bottle of tullamore dew
Wonderful combination of fruity and floral, very easy on the nose. One of my favorite go to's for Irish Whisky and a perfect representative of pot still whisky.
Very sweet nose, sugared shortbread cookies and light fruits. Sugar cookies on the taste, followed by mustiness.
I wish there were more single pot stills out there. This one counts.

Appearance: The color in this beautiful Irish whiskey is a light caramel hue. Legs within are thin and watery.

Nose: Fruity and sweet are my first impressions of the nose. Notes of plum, cherry, red wine, fresh cut hay, buttered toast, coconut, sunscreen, and snickerdoodle cookies all make their appearance and weave throughout each other. Also, I find the more I let it sit, the more it opens and starts to smell like an Old Fashioned with an orange peel garnish. An added splash of water creates more floral and honeyed, walking-through-the-woods-in-the-rain-on-a-warm-day note.

Taste: The palate also has a fruity first impression. There are notes of red apples, Twizzler candy, cinnamon sugar toast, and salted caramel. A splash of water brings out notes of yeasty sourdough bread and orange tang.

Finish: There is slight heat at first, easing into a mellower medium length, orange citrus finish.

Thoughts: Oh my gosh! I am so very impressed with this whiskey and it is easily my new favorite Irish, at least. I highly recommend it and would be happy to buy it again. Thank you Midleton, for this delight! Sláinte!

My first Irish whiskey other than Jameson. I loved this whiskey, I would strongly recommend it. Vanilla, honey, red apples, pears joined with sherry on the nose. Very complex nose, very sweet, a personal favorite nose. Touch of smokiness hidden. A short sweet creaminess on the palate then dominated by spice and toasted wood. Citrus note appears as well, orange peel. A bit of smokiness. Long aftertaste of wine, walnuts, toasted wood, and malted barley.
Absolutely delicious Irish whiskey that drinks like a bourbon.
Sweet and rich. Little bite at the end.
Very nice. Let’s you know you are drinking it.

Au nez : sec et froid avec une acidité métallique, noix de coco dominante, brioche, vanille, caramel, poire, avec une touche de fruits secs
Palais : salé et amer, presque acide, noix de coco, vanille, brioché, citron, légères épices, chêne après coup, une légère fumée boisée 
La finale est moyenne, sèche et vanillée puis laisse place à une note de coco

Note personnelle : 82

Un whisky sympathique sans pour autant tirer son épingle du jeu si ce n’est par sa touche de coco assez originale, à part cela un léger manque de rondeur, de complexité et des notes acides froides et métalliques qui ne plairont pas à tous.
Cela reste tout de même un bon whisky dans l’ensemble, pas désagréable

Fruity, a little peppery spice and sweets. Just as delicious as the Glenmorengies I recently tasted, the Quinta Ruban and the Lasanta, but a tiny bit less sweet and drier. The sweetness seems better integrated, not that sugary. Little bit salty as well. Definitely more oak. Love this one. 
That said, I am afraid that every single 12 year old sherry or port casked whiskey I buy will taste wonderfull, with differences way less obvious than most reviewers ever going to admit. 
This Irish whiskey could easily be a Scotch and in a blind tasting I would have a moderately hard time distinguish this one with say, Glenmorangie's Lasanta. But for now this Redbreast appears to be my favorite. But I could easily live with any of them. (So why not stick with one type bottle?)
berry jam, clove & spices in the back of the throat, mild honey, sweet and warming finish
Smooth front but spicy end like bourbon

I thought it high time I did another head to head tasting. This time around I'll be reviewing the four widely available expressions from Redbreast: the 12 year, 15 year, Lustau edition, and the 12 year Cask Strength (CS). I'd love to include the 21 year in this lineup but my wallet can't handle that sort of hit. If any of you fine folks would be willing to send a sample it'd be most appreciated. I'm also curious as to your opinions on my rankings and whether or not you'd rate these differently. Redbreast is one of my favorite whiskey brands and any of their expressions are worth having in your collection.

The classic Redbreast 12 pours into the glass with a beautiful golden color. The nose has beautifully layered aromas that dance between the biscuity pot still malts and the sherry casks. This one is a classic for a reason. While I'm normally wary of 40% abv offerings, this one seems like that's the right fit (after having fiddled around with the CS for a time). The taste is lovely, with just a little nip from the alcohol and smooth, buttery texture that warms your body as it goes down. The finish lingers nice and long. A supremely drinkable dram, and the benchmark for the rest of the line. I could drink this all day.

For today's tasting I'm rating this #1  out of 4.
Smooth, a little sweet. Nice with ice to temper.

Appearance:Nice thin legs
Nose:sweet with notes of citrus
Palate: sweet and slight caramel.
Finish: slight burn and citrus after taste.
Great Irish Whiskey

Only have 2 other irish whiskey to compare it to but in general it's ok. it's not as good as jameson caskmates stout edition and not as unique as sexton. For a whiskey,  it's as good as an average non peated scotch but I'm not buying average scotch. I need more complexity.
Citrus fruits on the nose. with the important exception Teeling , a lot of Irish whiskeys remind me of vodka
Smooth and rich with apricot and orange marmalade. Slight spice and oak at the end.
Rich, sweet, and smooth. Pastries, buttery shortbread cookies. Barrel spice and red apples on the finish.
Very oily palate with fruity honey malts. Hints of pear.
maple on the nose, spicy, strong
warm and lightly spicy, very smooth with some sweetness and great caramel flavor
I’d like to say I love this as much as everyone else, but I can’t. Not bad, just a little boring.

The nose: very dominate coconut, warm biscuit with honey

The pallete: buttered toast, oily mouth feel, tart, wood bitterness

The finish: short to medium length, oily, barrel bitterness

Overall, a great Irish, super friendly. The nose is much nicer than the pallete
everything a pot still Irish whiskey should be
Uniquely Irish. Shortbread cookie, hints of gingerbread and grapes, short to medium finish. Pretty damn good and very easy drinking. Fairly oily

Nose: fantastic sweetness, vanilla and oranges.

Taste: full and rich, cake, fruit pastry.

Finish: nearly non existent, very short lived but also very smooth exit. Hint of fresh bread
The quintessential style of Irish whiskey. Full bodied, rich with amazing dark fruits and nuttiness.
Very smooth and warm. Surprisingly sweet.

Nose: Candied sweet. Berry short bread.
Taste : Shortbread and berries. Sweet with only a hint of alcohol burn.
Very smooth entrance and nice malted burn to finish. Has a rich buttery nose and overall sweet notes are spectacular.
Prefer the 12yr old Cask Strength but for the price, this can't be beat.  My go to Irish to sip while relaxing at home.
Nice aroma with a hint of cloves. Smooth vanilla and honey taste. A nice creamy oily mouthfeel. Warm pepper spice on the back end that lasts.
"Complex, spicy, and fruity; Long, sweet aftertaste; classic Irish whiskey with complexities not found in others"
Poured at a fancy sports bar. Easy to drink but fairly nondescript taste. Not interesting.
Smooth vanilla and honey start with a nice  spicy finish. A nice silky mouthfeel throughout.
Perfect drink for it's price point. If I could only buy one liquor for the rest of my life, it would either be this, or Johnny Walker Black.

Nose:  citrus, apple, honey, floral
Palate: thick mouthfeel, rich, sweet, floral, malt, mild spice 
Finish: long finish, mild spice, sweet, floral
Super tasty, smooth, vanilla, wood hints

Juicy apple, caramel, I don’t know what it is, it feels like a well balanced whisky but there is something unpleasant about it. Gasoline, whine gum. 
With substantial amount of added water: gingerbread
Very sweet, chocolate, nuts and dried fruits. Very pleasant.
Vanilla, popcorn, hazelnut mocha cake, smooth, oily mouthfeel.
Honey and green apple Jolly Rancher on the nose. A nice mouthfeel. A bit oily and really buttery smooth.
Rich and spicy with what I would characterize as an oak-y/cedar-y finish. I really enjoy this as an after dinner sipping whiskey.

Nose 👃; Vanilla, light sherry, oranges, sweet,
Taste 👅; Red fruits, florals, some honey, some spicy pepper, 
Finish ; Creamy and rich, 

This one is really balanced and nice, probably my new Irish whiskey favourite 👌
Len god. Typisk irland fast bättre
Super good. Quite spicy up front. Hints of Carmel.

Deeply enjoyable, but missing a little je-ne-sais-quois... Maybe proof? I really ought to try the CS. Still, it's got some wonderful dried fruits, oak tannins, and spice. Plus that buttery texture. Felt like I missed out on the hype... Maybe just the flight I had it in?
Red apple and some spicyness on nose. Palate: sweet and  spiceyness comes a bit later. Long spicey finish. Creaminess remains for long.
Great! First scotch I've really enjoyed

It’s funny to me, that I’m over 500 whisky reviews deep and I’ve yet to officially review this Irish whiskey staple:  Redbreast 12.  I’ve even reviewed a few other offerings from Redbreast- just not the 12.  I keep thinking that I’ve tried this before, but then again maybe I haven’t.  Weird.  Anyway, this sample was sent to me by my buddy @Generously_Paul, from Michigan.  It’s bottled at 40% ABV, is triple distilled, chill filtered and probably has added color that makes it lightly coppered in the taster.  It makes some fat, yet undefined legs after a spin and leaves behind medium sized droplets clinging to the lip.  It also looks rather watery, in general.

The nose starts out spicier than I anticipated.  There’s a healthy dose of vanilla, nut bread and citrus peel.  I don’t get much, if any, sweetness but then again I didn’t let this one sit very long.  Some barrel cask presence sent a quick sting up my nose as I has going in for the first sip.  Speaking of sips, the Christmas spices and something equivalent to rye spice launched onto my tongue very quickly- it also caught me off guard.  After a bit of a roll, the spice note subsided and warm oak and vanilla settled in along with a nutty almond back end.  It’s pleasant enough, albeit a tad harsh- even at 40%. The finish was short and still spicy, but left plenty of vanilla lingering for a bit.  A sip of water a few moments later washed it all away.  There’s zero staying power with this whiskey.

Overall, I seem to be very unimpressed with most Irish whiskies: except for West Cork and Bushmills.  Redbreast, Teeling and Jameson don’t inspire me into buying more of their offerings.  None of these are bad whiskies, they all just seem a little too tame for me.  This particular 12 year old is the ultimate middle of the road dram IMHO.  2.5 stars.  Cheers.
This is quickly becoming my go to
Fruity, sweet.  No peat.  Taste a hint of Sherry cask.
First Irish whiskey and it’s pretty good. Still prefer bourbon but tasty.
Smooth delivery of toffee, toasted oak, vanilla, and red fruit. Slight bite in the end, mellowed by sarsaparilla notes.

Nose: Burnt toast and orange marmalade, quite pleasant and friendly. 
Taste: Cloves and a spicy oak lead into a long finish of buttery cinnamon buns, burned at the edges.
Smooth and sweet, almond and vanilla nose with nutty, caramel taste
A very pleasant tipple, but a bit boozy.

Nose: citrus peel, honey, shortbread cookie
Palate: peach/nectarine, buttery cookies, orange peel
Finish: long, viscous, buttery

Nose: Honey, shortbread cookie, slight vanilla. Surprisingly strong alcohol nose for only a 40 ABV whisky.

Palatte: slightly sweet, honey butter biscuit. Mild vanilla butter cookie flavor. Very light, friendly. Extremely short finish with bitter oak notes capping off flavor.

Nose: The olorosso appears immediately with dark red fruit notes, plum and grapes. Vanilla, butter and slight floral notes follow with custard, heavy peach jam and cooking spices; nutmeg and baked apple tart. Sweetened apples and grape juice linger.

Palate: A brief smoke appears initially with cloves, toasted barley and cinnamon. Very apparent sweetness of green apple and buttered tart, reminding of rhubarb pie. Pecans and malt mix with orange zest and cream.

Finish: Medium finish with very brief hint of smoke, nuts and orange rind

The beginning of the whiff is totally a bourbon, but the end of the whiff is a highland scotch. Left me confused about what to expect.

Definitely no bourbon in the taste, no vanillas or caramel. Toffee is there. This Irish is as middle as they come honestly: not too harsh, not too sweet, not too light, not heavy at all.

Finish is pretty smooth. Don’t know if I’d buy a whole bottle tho. I’d probably buy the bottle for one of those sissy friends who can’t really handle the full scotches, ya know?

Oh, Redbreast. If I were a poet, I would write a sonnet about you. But I’m not, so here’s an average whiskey review. This Irish is more full than most, but not robust, by any means. Pleasantly sweet, but refreshingly not suuuper sugary sweet. I could actually drink this for an extended period of time. Heavy on the toffee, but I’m perfectly fine hanging out there. Sherry character is pronounced, and it avoids the sulfur follow-up characteristic of some other sherried whiskeys I’ve had. Can barely taste the alcohol, and smooth as all get out. The finish lingers. Fantastic Irish.
Prior to reading others tasting notes, I was getting a baked apple pie and cinnamon. After reading other tasting notes I can find orange, vanilla and other notes descriptors.
Neat it definitely had the punch in the front as described on the box but the punch was good. On the rocks it was more smoot and tastier and a mellowed punch
Apple pie,  a touch of smoke.   Smooth finish
Vanilla short finish sharp nose spice wood. Citrus peel nose

Nose: Definite barley sweetness.  Ripe stone fruits.  Cereal grain sweetness.

Palate: Barley front and center.  Ripe banana with baking spices.  Sweet.  The middle of the palate gives me coffee with a hint of sweetened cocoa.  Buttery biscuits with honey.  Slight mustiness - like old dusty books.

Other notes: I'm not often one for Irish, but Redbreast is a definite favorite.  Beautiful, beautiful sipper.
A step above! Smooth and delicious.

Had this many times through the years but picked up bottle for formal review. Have always considered this the best Irish ive ever had including Middletons. on to the review.............. So Zues is sitting at the table with Ares , Apollo, Athena and the other gods after a big feast. He says now we drink! The servants bring out the glasses and pour a dram of the most wonderful nectar in all the lands. Dionysus peeks under the serving cart and spots the bottle of Redbreast 12 and smiles................Yes its only 80 proof and yes its expensive but the buttery creamy pot still texture is sooooo smooth you wont care. Doesn't matter if you're a bourbon, rye, scotch or any type liquor guy you can fall in love with this. Not overly complex or a whiskey you need to dissect instead its the most approachable pleasant whiskey out there. Pour this for anyone, pure happiness in a glass. Tasting notes are just not necessary other than distilled joy...........93/100..........ok a few notes... Its soft and sweet with honey and caramel with perfect amount of oak. Silky smooth rich and malty with nice finish. It is overpriced but sometimes you just gotta go for it. I did get it on sale for $50 though
Odd nose, perhaps it’s pine that I’m smelling? Light and sweet palate, characteristic of Irish whisky (reminds me of bush mills red) with a nutty finish. Tiny bit of heat but generally pretty smooth

On the nose very sweet vanilla apricot marmalade.

On the palate it's very comfortable, tasty a bit burning.

Long finish with a very good taste.

Probably one of the best Irish and very cheap
Simple the best irish Whisky I have tested.

Nose: vanilla and figs
Taste: first slightly acidic and spicy, then it mellows down. 
Finish: caramel 

OK to drink. Wouldn’t buy a bottle
One of the finest whiskey. Taste is rich ginger to cinnamon, sherry notes elegant finish. Good blend of malted & unmalted. Top5
Rich flavor, good taste, short finish. Best irish

Smooth smooth smooth. And there is flavor too. Oh yeah, did I say it’s smooth?

An Irish Whiskey for the thinking man.

Nose:
Ohhh mamma, buttery, malty and sweet.
Baked red apples mixed with zingy yellows
Toffee, smashed oily walnuts and flowers.

Palate:
Oh so rich and luscious. 
Buttery cream, vanilla cookies and walnuts
Baking spices, pie crust and soft peaches
Freshly sanded wood and soft vanilla
Everything is rich yet delicate

Finish:
Long, slow, meandering and thick.
All the cream, spice and fruit give you a hug

Nose: bready and light, the unmalted barley really helps offset the overly yeasty nose that many single malt scotches exhibit, hints of oak, vanilla, caramel and honey

The nose and palate both are quite bright while also maintaining a complexity and richness. 

Palate: quite rich, as the age really shines in those oloroso sherry casks, and the single pot still opens up those grains; very balanced, and not too malty, nice vanilla spices and hints of citrus 

Finish: medium but the 80 proof drizzles down very smoothly. 

One of the richest 80-proof whiskeys you’ll taste. It’s quite impressive.  This is also a great starter whiskey for bourbon fans to try when they want to branch out.
Every time I try this I get something different. Tonight it's apple, wine, lemon and wood on the nose. Bit of an ethanol burn. Oily in the mouthfeel, a bit salty, oaky, tannic, sour. Excellent stuff.
For now, the best Irish whiskey I’ve ever had
Very smooth, light fruity notes, warm
Round, bright apple, fruit.  Both light and rich.  Nice, balanced wood/malt. Easy to drink. Really delicious.
Lots of layers in this Irish. Love this tasty buttery note on the palette. One of my favorite Irish whiskeys.

Incredibly smooth, creamy, and light entry, with notes of sweet cereal and citrus custard, which morph into a creamy coconut-milk with dried rich-fruits.  The finish is a long honeysuckle, creamy and still remaining smooth.

Very sippable, although the ABV is a bit low, this is a year-round cabinet staple that is balanced and just as good to the noob as the experienced Irish whiskey drinker.

You ever walked into a house where dessert baking is happening in real time? Where Christmas music is playing and there’s flour all over the place and your grandma has her apron on wielding a rolling pin like a surgeon’s scalpel? Redbreast is about baking. It’s about dessert. It’s about comfort.

Nose: Butter, sugar cookies, vanilla, the slightest lemon peel

Taste: it’s creamy. It’s coconut and caramel. Gosh it’s so good.

Slightest spice on the finish.
My god. This is so good. Super complex and fruity. No heat at all at 40%
Very rich with sweet and oak body.
I enjoyed the cereal taste of the unmalted barley.
Smooth.  Toasted caramel and sweet notes

Neat in glencairn, sit for 10min
Nose: flora, banana, fruity, spices, vanilla 
Palate: sweet, creamy, vanilla, toasty, coconut, sherry
Finish: light, malty
The best Irish Whiskey. Soft, and smooth, buttery biscuits, slight cinnamon and spicy notes. Oh, so good.
Spicy, well rounded with sweet orange notes
Fantastic Irish whiskey. Very smooth, rich and full body and smooth finish. Tasted at El Moro, $9 a glass?
One of my favorite Irish whiskeys
Most flavor I've ever had for an Irish whiskey
Very long finish,  full of spice.

My favorite Irish at the moment. Twelve years for this is what 15 years is to many other whiskeys sans maybe bourbon. 

Nose: bright, great balance of barley notes with candied vanilla and butterscotch, hints of apple and honey biscuits

Palate: sweet vanilla, pears and light nutmeg

Finish: medium which is the weakest point of this whiskey. But overall fantastic.
Lighter body and profile but flavorful.  Clean orange peel, honey notes.  My favorite Irish whiskey.
Smooth, a bit of caramel, short, not a lot to say. Good but a bit simple.
Solid Irish whiskey. Fruity, sweet and light. Apple, pear and honey notes throughout. Honestly not super memorable and a bit too light for my taste. Love to try the CS version.
This was my first bottle. And therefore didmt really get any taste notes. Only that i knew i liked it and it tasted very good
Simply became one of my favorites
Very sweet a little spicy. Smooth Irish whiskey.
Forward spice that quick tames to a smooth finish with little burn
Insanely smooth, balanced bouquet of flavor. Pure magic.

Neat - smooth, low on spice,  notes of caramel and sweetness 

Rocks - brings out hints of apple and intensifies the caramel flavor

Redbreast 12 pours Oily and Clingy into the Glencairn.
Nose: The nose is mild, but complex. Malt and Fruit forward. Apple, Pear, Grape. A hint of Citrus (think Icebox Lemon Pie). Oatmeal with Brown Sugar, Sherry, Pencil Shavings, Fresh Paint, and Oak. Lots of great smells that I can't quite pin down. The longer it stays in the glass the more the Brown Sugar Sweetness dominates. I could nose this for hours.
Neat: Nice Heavy Oily Coating Mouthfeel. A little Black Pepper tingle at first, fading to Grape, Milk Chocolate, Marshmallow, Coconut, and Pencil Shavings. There is a little Bitterness. Just the mildest heat on the finish. Mild Malty Sweetness coats and lingers. Much like the nose, the palate gets sweeter with time.
Splash: Really makes the Brown Sugar prominent on the nose. Vanilla and Brown Sugar take center stage on the palate.
Verdict: Really Good, but not Great. Just can't quite bring myself to give it that quarter star, but it's oh so close. I'd love to try this in cask strength as I think it would make some of the more subtle notes bolder. I do not regret the $65 price tag, but I will make this bottle last a while at that price.
Excellent. Sweet spicy briney goodness. Easy in easy down, with a hint of pepper/cinnamon. Dried fruit, dark fruit.
Tasted as a set with the 15 year and Lustau. This came off a little sharp compared to the others.  Honey notes with a mellow burn. A nice sipper after it sat out for a few minutes.

N - Sherry orange vanilla

P - creamy smooth sweet Sherry honey

F - medium long finish

Nose: Underripe oranges, green apple, shortbread cookies.  Creamy - that pot still mustiness is really well balanced here.  Vanilla.  Crème brûlée.  Earthy nutmeg and allspice. Figs.  Cocoa.  Sweet, but in a delicate sense.  Very friendly and inviting without being flat and boring.

Palate: There's that soft, creamy. sweet vanilla again.  Earth, nutmeg, and allspice slowly give way to the most understated cinnamon note.  Coffee, a little leather, milk chocolate.  This is mostly mid palate - not necessarily a bad thing.  The sherry cask shows up, along with subtle tannin character.  Finish starts off with chocolate covered coffee beans and orange zest.  That slowly turns into bitter chocolate ice cream, but with a little more vanilla than usual.  Slowly everything disappears from the bottom up - eventually left with bananas, orange peel, and then finally cocoa powder.

Other notes: I am really glad I'm revisiting this.  I recognized the quality here the first time I had this, but I sold it short due to my own preconceptions with Irish whiskey.  Coming back to this with a more open mind has given the a chance to recognize just how good this stuff really is.  The execution with this stuff is top notch.  Every single person I've suggested it to has had the same reaction - "Woah".  Well worth having a bottle on hand.
Great whiskey. So smooth it's scary.

This one is truly a lovely whiskey.  The flavors are rich and balanced overall, displaying red fruit, honey, clove, toasted cereal. While there is a noted creaminess in the mouth, to me it is less than the Green Spot. This also has slightly more heat and has a slight astringency on the finish---not uncommon in sherry finishes.
Very bread-y. A bit of spice and a bit of fruit. Baked goods and the like. Goes down easy.
A other good, but nothing special whiskey. Mellow. Middle of the road.

Nose: honey, freshly peeled oranges, slight grassy note, a bit of nose burn
Palate: sweet, vanilla, pear
Finish: lengthy, creamy
Floral. Thick. Not hot. Short finish
Super peppery finish. Needed an ice cube to open it up. Nice Carmel vanilla smell
Will skip with the tasting notes. Flat out this is one of my favorite whiskies. I would drink this every single day if I could
One of my favorite Irish whiskeys.
Sweet, smooth, and well rounded whiskey

Clove and pepper leading to apple and dried fruit. Creamy with a long finish. Just a little sour at the end.
Very much want to try the barrel proof.
Delicious neat or with ice ball.  An undeniably smooth and solid Irish.  Slightly hard to justify the price point though, with so much competition coming in below this bottle's cost.
This is an amazing sample of an Irish whisky well executed. It definitely punches above its weight at only $70
Delicious. Sweet but subtle. Easy but complex. Worth a buy.

Sweet scent
Salty
Caramel, honey
Minty finish
Fruit and honey, creamy taste, long finish. Well balanced.
Very good, smooth, unique, and a great sipper

I might be biased cause this is my first dram after a dry week AND I drank it while watching the return of Conor McGregor but damn Redbreast is a damn great whiskey. Amazing fruity light notes on the nose and a beautiful vanilla cookie taste that fades into an almost strawberry finish. It's amazingly creamy and light. I've still got some left in the glass because I just can't finish it as fast as other whiskeys. It deserves more respect than that.
Oak, vanilla, honey, baking spice, and dried cherry on the nose. Palate is honey, oak, spicy barrel, and malt. A terrific Irish expression.
Buttery smooth, but not getting as much flavor tonight.

I am an infamously big sipper and I'm taking the smallest sips of this possible because it's that damn good. Lots of creamy, buttery notes on the nose with small hints of berry playing at the back. A lot of flavor coming through on the palate with an almost orange marmalade-meets-coconut taste that eventually settles into a nice finish that almost reminds me of those Snowball cupcakes.

Sweet floral smell, pretty light color. Mostly grain and wood on the tongue, but it's a bit stronger than most Irish whiskies I've tasted, which I like. I get and wonderful sweetness of light fruits on the tail, apple and pear, which is longer than expected. I like this better than the 15 personally.
The sherry notes come through with a mild sweetness of dried candies fruit. Easily one of the best Irish whiskeys available.

Finally an Irish that I would drink regularly. While mild and light there is some complexity here to make it unique. I find orange marmalade and brown sugar up front with dried cherry and burnt toast on the finish.

Musty, candied oranges and cherries on the nose, creamy palate with more subtle orange notes plus some honey and biscuits, short bread cookies, orange marmalade and baking spices on the medium length finish. This is a great whiskey!
Light and buttery. Very smooth on the finish

Despite being aged only in sherry casks, this whiskey isn’t a sherry bomb. It only gives hints of cooked fruits and spices as a counterpoint to your standard Irish shortbread cookie flavors. Adding a bit of water brings out some pronounced buttery notes which are great. Adding an ice cube really brings out the sweetness. All-around enjoyable.

It’s not as smooth as I’d like it to be. Still a little spiky and phenolic. Makes me wish I had enough to shell out for a higher age statement, but the bottom-rung version is overpriced enough.
Very sweet and fresh, with a hint of vanilla

Nose - melon, vanilla, cereal

Taste- butter, danish cookies, melon, tangy
Honey and toasted coconut on the nose.  Very full, rich flavour with the sherry casks being notable.  Long grainy, chewy finish. One of my all time favourite whiskys.
Loved this whiskey ❤️ probably the best I have had so far
Very good pour, always pleasing, better than the 15.
Smooth and warm with a hint of butterscotch, honey and a little fruit. Very enjoyable.

Słodka, owocowa, łagodna. 
Węch - orzechy 
Finish - kokos

Refreshing sea spray, red apple, and maybe even shoe polish on the nose, along with a lot of biscuit in the mouth.  Generically fruity finish.  So cool and balanced that you can drink it almost without noticing, but that also means (for me, anyway) that there’s not a ton of excitement here.  Looking forward to trying the Lustau and the 15 for a little something different.
Just a lovely expression of Irish whiskey.  Buttery biscuits and shortbread.
Sweet and fruity. I get honey and fruit. Super smooth.
Clean and strong, nice finish. Neat.

Nose: Sweet caramel
Taste: Simple. Sweet. Orange marmalade 
Finish: Quick syrup sweetness.
Extremely smooth. Warm finish. Maybe some cedar notes. Would love to compare this to the 15 and 21

Noses light, fruits and bread. Hits the palate with pear and malt, followed by some light oak. This causes my salivary glands to come out, so it reminds me of a juicy and crisp mouthfeel. Yes it is smooth.
Smooth and not peaty. Def drink again
The first "nice" whiskey I had after Jameson. Showed me that there is levels to this whiskey thing. I remember it having a lot more depth and complexity than your typical Irish
Fruity, Spicy and a hint of Vanilla
It’s good - sweet, fruity - but I prefer bourbon.

Nose: Honey and fresh apple
Taste: Buttered cookie and barrel spice
Very enjoyable and pleasant, lingering dried fruits
Very good. Smooth, mellow, slightly sweet. Not smokey or peaty.
Spicy honey bite with creamy mouthfeel and oaky finish
Gorgeous rich buttery caramel & cognac smell. Medium smoothness.

Redbreast 12 is a Single Pot Still Irish Whiskey, triple distilled in copper pot stills, and matured for at least 12 years in American ex-bourbon and Spanish Oloroso sherry casks. This maturation process instills the robust and complex sherry style distinctive qualities that are truly breathtaking. Made from a mash of malted and unmalted barley, Redbreast 12 is bottled at a gentle 80 proof/40% ABV.

Color: Copper Gold

Nose: Rich fruitiness, red berries, sherry, nutty (almonds/cashews), creamy sweetness, floral, and toasted wood.

Palate: Silky and smooth, red berries, buts, charred oak, leather, sherry, creamy, and mild spiciness.

Finish: Long and spicy, lingering sherry, leather, and toasted wood.

Nose: sweet, fruity, almost like jam and butter on toast

Taste: sweet, rich, complex, deep, fruit notes and spice with toasted oak

Nose- very tropical. Banana and apple forward.
Palate- Heavy vanilla and banana on the front followed by green apples.
Finish- medium finish with green apple tapering off.

Toffee, vanilla, orange and maybe something floral on the nose. Palate is surprisingly creamy/oily, sweet up front but closes with a marked wood spice note and a little bitterness. It’s my first single pot still whiskey, undeniably good, but maybe my expectations were a tad higher.
Creamy vanilla butter shortbread. Very good Irish.

Thought I'd celebrate St. Patrick's Day with my second pour from my bottle of Redbreast 12. After this review, I went back and read my notes from the first tasting and I don't know if I've ever had two reviews sound so close together. For some reason I enjoyed it a tick more this time, so it earned that extra quarter star.

NOSE: Love it. Sweet. Cola, Fruit, Honey, Melon, Oatmeal with Brown Sugar. A little Leather and a Floral note round it out. After some time in the glass, the nose is dominated by warm Sticky Brown Sugar and Butter.
NEAT: Decent Clinging Mouthfeel. Sweet. Dessert-Like. Cooked Apples with Brown Sugar and a sprinkle of Cinnamon. Pralines, Sweetened Cream, and Honeycomb. An odd, but not unpleasant note of Pencil Shavings. A Little Bitter or Sour Note on the finish. A slight warming on the way down with Vanilla Sweetness coating. A hint of the Sourness also remains. I get very little Barrel Influence in this.
SPLASH: A little water doesn't change much, but it does reduce that sourness a little. However, it does so at the expense of some of the more complex palate notes.
VERDICT: Like I said, this whisky must be pretty consistent pour to pour as my notes were very similar from 1st pour to 2nd. This is still my favorite Irish so far.

Biscuit and some flowers I can't identify, maybe honeysuckle, slight vanilla on the nose. It's so delicate it can be difficult to pick out specific things.
Taste is like a light, fluffy bourbon. Vanilla, pastry, buttery, shortbread cookies, some honey. It's nice, but maybe too delicate for my taste.

Nose - spice, vanilla and some nutty sweetness
Taste - vanilla and spiced honey, toffee and a hint of pepper at the end
Finish - silky and sweet, pleasant and oily, a bit of spice at the end

Spicy up front but smooth, slightly oily mouthfeel with a nice lingering tingle on the back of the tongue that has a mix of caramel/toffee and a nice buttery shortbread bite that lasts for quite a while.

Happy St. Patty's day! Suck it COVID-19. Caramel, vanilla, butterscotch, honeysuckle, cooked fruit, hint of spice and oak. Oily with a creamy mouth feel. I'm primarily a bourbon and rye guy but this is stellar. Great pour!

Nose: I get luxardo/dark cherry and black licorice on the nose

Palate: Much richer than most Irish whiskeys. Oily but not overbearing. Great pale gold color. 

Well worth the price. Even better than green spot and others in this range. If you like Irish whiskey you can never go wrong with this bottle.
A pleasant experience from start to finish. Interesting dough on the nose and palate followed by a smooth finish leaving a surprising hint of sweetness behind.
Excellent single pot still   No whiskey kick and very smooth.  Much better with ice
Fruity, biscuits, apples, classic Irish taste but richer.
Vanilla and dried apricot on the nose. The pallet is rich and smooth with more dried fruit, and an almost-citrusy finish.
Old favorite of mine. Smooth, yet more distinct thsn alot of Irish whisky.
Citrus peel, laminate wood, vanilla to the nose. Crisp and clean, mellow, watermelon skin, with a slight brine after taste.
Great Irish whiskey - so smooth. A little of a classic Irish whiskey taste to it but not at all bad.

The nose is raisins and toffee.  On the palate: sherry notes balanced by honey - and also the oak, coming across as shortbread.  The shortbread continues very briefly on the mid-palate, before the finish when the oak gets slightly bitter. The baking spices then make an understated appearance.  The spice does intensify into a warming sensation if you quaff away back to back sips.   But it's mellow and held back by the low 40% ABV.  Like all good ex-sherry casked whiskies, this makes for a great cold weather drink, but it can be perfectly agreeable during the warmer months as well.

The Redbreast 12 is a standard among sherried whiskies.  With a friendlier palate than another standard, the Macallan 12 Sherry Oak, this is a reliable dram for a movie or happy hour event.  It's a whiskey that doesn't take you on much of a journey.  You don't have to spend a lot of time picking at it's nuances.  It's good and simple.



My Rating Glossary:  

Two Stars:           "I'd rather be drinking lite beer."
Two 1/2 Stars:    "Posh rubbish."
Three Stars:        "I love whisk(e)y.  This is average love."
Three 1/2 Stars: "May buy again."
Four Stars:          "I've got to get you into my life."
Four 1/2 Stars:   "Better than drugs."
Five Stars:           "Life is good.  Whisky makes it better."

Nose: warm sweetish, hint of banana, aceton
Taste: smooth, honeylike, spicy
Finish : modest, but lasting, some liquorice

Great nose: sweet, almost red berry, red apple peel.
Taste: orange marmalade, vanilla, shoe polish

Nose: Apple Blossoms and Red Berries. Vanilla and Honey drizzled Biscuits. Caramel

Finish: Taffy Apple
Sweet, soft, nice finish. Creamy, fruity
So far my favorite Irish whiskey. Nice balance of fruit and spice. Palate reminds me of fruitcake without actually tasting like that vile dessert bread. Rich and smooth flavor that long lasting.
Super smooth and creamy. Nice vanilla and biscuit flavor. Love the finish and the buttery linger afterwards
Very smooth.  Very buttery. I no longer dislike Irish whiskey.

I like this one. It smells of under ripe pears and sourdough. The taste has light oak, pears and a bit of orange zest. There are underlying notes of sunflower seeds and raw dough.

The finish is sweet and peppery with a touch of fresh whip cream.

This whiskey makes me think a lot of spring time.
Fruitiest Irish I’ve tasted.  Hints of floral with a thin mouthfeel.
Not quite what I was expecting. Light and flitful like the bird on the box. Also some red fruit notes. The familiar Irish unmalted twang has been severely muted. A bit of a disappointment.

Nose-Sweet caramel sherry 
Taste-Creamy short bread
Lots of spices yet light and fruity

Nose is sherry and oak. Taste is bright and grassy with good mouthfeel.  There is a complex mossy undertone that tastes slightly unpleasant.  Finish is long and complex, like sour raisins, and it lingers with bitterness. I can tell it’s a high quality whiskey but the flavor profile is not for me.

ドライフルーツのおかげか、フルーティで爽やかである。

ココナッツぽさはあるが、おそらく入ってないのでわりかし好みの味である。

This whisky contains dry fruits, it feels very fruity and so fresh.

This is not Coconuts taste, so it’s my favorite one comparatively.
No nonsense whiskey. Very similar nose and taste to bourbon. Like a ginger snap cookie
Spicy.  Smooth.  I really enjoyed this.
Clean, smooth and enjoyable to sip neat.
Butter, biscuits, and honey. Very smooth and enjoyable
I just like scotch so much better
Wonderful creamy orange flavor, full and smooth.
There's nothing like Redbreast (that I know of). It's subtle, but what's there, is magic.

The nose on a neat pour in a glencairn is soft, warm and welcoming. Unlike a Jameson which is bright and fruity and shouts at you to pay attention, Redbreast 12 doesn’t need to. Apple, dark candied fruit, caramel and oak all wrapped nicely in a malted package is what it presents.

Palate starts off sweet and smooth, and then there is Granny Smith apple for days, mixed with butter and warmed baking spices that remind you of your first apple pie. 

The finish is dry but lingers, which you don’t expect, but sure appreciate it when you’re there.  The malted barley that presented at the nose comes back for an encore now, with the sherry cask and wood notes rounding it out. 

This whiskey begs you to slow down, take your time and enjoy the rich nuanced flavours it has to offer. A really solid representation of what Pot Still Irish can be.
Everything they say about it is true!!! Amazing!!!
Mellow and smooth, slightly sweet- minimal peat

You'd be forgiven for thinking this an avec in a blind tasting. A glorious sweet sipper dominated by fruits and nuts. My benchmark for Irish pot whiskey that has yet to be toppled. 

While the 15y edition is also glorious it adds very little to the already complete experience that the 12y provides.

Redbreast are at the forefront of Irish whiskey and they know it, which clearly shows in the price. A bargain this is not, but a coveted glass to pour when you want a delicious punctuation to an evening.
Became a favourite at first sip.

Neat, no water. Glencairn.

Nose: Mostly oak, some sweetness coming through.

Palate: Sweetness through and through. Warm and full. Strong caramel. Tastes like candy.

Finish: More caramel. Short finish.

Neat, no water back needed. 

Nose: easy on the nose but nothing epic that stood out, hint of sweet
Palate: light feel, smooth start to finish. Can definitely pick out the sherry influence in the sweetness toward the end. Good one to keep around, interested to try older ones!
